 Hello and welcome to my ZipCon 2021 conference.
Quite stoked to be here as this is my third time at ZipCon, but actually the first time
when I'm presenting.
And given what amazing guests ZipCon team always managed to get to present at the conference,
I'm really proud and glad that this year I had a chance to present my point of view.
What we're going to talk today is intelligence requirements, and in particular, how to make
the requirements work for your organization in a way that they will effectively align
the needs of the intelligence team and the incident response and security operations,
meaning monitoring and detection teams, so that they can work in concerto and deliver
the results that will be beneficial for whole organization without misalignment of the expectations
on both sides and without misunderstandings about what those teams can do.
So starting with a bit about me, currently I'm a consulting engineer at Cisco.
I'm working on threat intelligence and threat hunting issues with the Cisco customers.
Earlier, I worked in the various hunting and intelligence roles, well, mainly, or I also
work as an incident responder, first-line SOC analyst, and so on.
Earlier, I got my law degree, I worked academically a bit on the national security and countering
cybercrime issues, including use of digital forensics by the law enforcement.
And for today's presentation, this is my professional experience in information security and moving
from those different roles to finally working on this implementation and issues of threat
intelligence was an inspiration in a way that I started recently thinking quite about not
only focusing not only on the technical aspects of threat intelligence, the latest reverse
engineering developments, how to track the infrastructure and so on, but how to effectively
implement intelligence programs in the organization and how to make things work so that intelligence
will be seen as a facilitator and force multiplier instead of just, you know, a cost center and
a burden and that nobody knows what to do with those intelligence reports.
If you will have any questions or will want to reach me after the presentation, please
feel free to, I'm on Twitter, on LawSecNet, feel free to email me or just connect on LinkedIn
and drop the private message.
So let's start with the definition of the intelligence requirements.
This is the quick one that I grabbed from the pre-dictionary based on the dictionary
of military and associated terms.
So intelligence requirements and the subject general or specific upon which there is a
need for the collection of information or the production of intelligence or a requirement
for intelligence to fill a gap in the command's knowledge or understanding of the battle space
or threat force.
And for today's topic, I think the second definition will be especially important one
because the filling the gap is exactly what we'll be talking about and what is the purpose
of the threat intelligence team in modern security organization, at least in my view.
So the role of the intelligence will be in security operations will be to either fill
the gap of what is needed by the incident responders to more effectively and more efficiently
remediate and contain the incident or in terms of monitoring to fill the detection gaps so
that the team will be equipped better to detect more and more advanced threats in terms of
what they are doing now with the detections.
Sorry about that.
So figuring out that each presentation will have probably one of those.
This is my take on the Suez Canal MEMS.
So what we'll be talking about today is focus and allocation of resources.
So just as we saw these little excavators having to initially deal with the mass that
the giant ship ever given has done to the Suez Canal, regardless of how well-resourced
and big your intelligence team is, it is very unlikely that you will be able to cover all
the sources, sorry, all the threats that are relevant to your organization.
So especially in current landscape, when you've got APT, you've got some state sponsor actors
and on top of that, or even not the other way around, but you've got those on top of
the numerous e-crime activities, ransomware incident, and so on.
It's not very likely that your team will have a chance to efficiently and properly analyze
each of those and deliver the perfect reporting.
So the intelligence requirements will help in focusing those efforts on what is most
relevant in the day-to-day operation and what can be, sorry, and which focus of the intelligence
will have most meaningful impact.
So to start us up with just one more MEMS is that when you think about the intelligence
products, especially if your intelligence team is a bit more advanced and is not satisfied
just with parsing open source reporting or getting some threat feeds and parsing them
for the purpose of introduction into your security program, actually it will be often
the case that intelligence team and operations team will want the same thing at the same
time.
So that incident responders or monitoring team will come to the intelligence and say
that they want the latest information on the threat trends and what is going on and
what should they look for in detection or how they can contextualize the incident so
they know how to remediate it proper and so on and so on.
And then intelligence team will come at the operation team with similar request that they
want to see the latest activity of what you saw so they can exploit and analyze it and
disseminate it and maybe make a cool blog post or cool presentation for ZipCon or another
conference and they want to dig into those implant samples to reverse engineer it and
so on and so on.
So to avoid being stuck with this, let's say, loop of everybody wanting the same thing on
the same time, it is important to establish the expectation of what each team can
deliver and how most effectively this intelligence process can start for both sides of this dilemma.
Preparing for this presentation, I wanted to see what are the trends in the intelligence
requirements and I looked at the SANS 2021 Cyber Threat Intelligence Survey and regarding
the use or documentation of intelligence requirements as opposed to those or to creating
them ad hoc, it seems that the situation is not changing that much.
So you can see that approximately 30-40% got the document requirements, 30-40% got them
ad hoc and about 6% got no plans to define them at all.
So it seems that approximately 40% got the document requirements and this does not change
much.
What is kind of either surprising or I think should change is on the right side graphics
that you see regarding who contributes to the CTI requirements.
So not surprisingly, we've got security operations, CTI personnel and incident response and at
the top three positions and in fact this is what we are going to talk about today, about
this interaction, but in my view this CTI team involvement in the requirements is too
low by approximately 30%.
So as I will talk about in a minute, I think that it's highly beneficial for the threat
intelligence team to be involved in the creation of requirements.
You can even say that it's absolutely necessary for that to be the case to avoid some misalignments
or lack of understanding of what's going on.
So the problem with intelligence in general is that making intelligence is easy.
Of course there is an asterisk here, like it's a lot of hard work to track the infrastructure
and to analyze the samples and analyze incidents and intrusions and so on and so on to categorize
them, cluster the activity.
But in general, if you've got intelligence team and you will tell them to produce some
intelligence, I don't think it will be hard for them to do so.
They will certainly put out great reports and show you the trends and so on and can
do presentation on the latest iteration of malware.
But if it won't be directed in a proper way, this can very, very quickly diverge into this
directionless intelligence when what the intelligence team is doing is very much separated from
the operations and day-to-day work of the people on the frontline.
And this is a very undesirable situation, obviously.
Both because the input from the intelligence will not help the operation, which is a major
bugger, but also because the intelligence team will be more seen as the burden rather
than helpful part of the organization.
So making the relevant and actionable intelligence is harder because it involves working with
stakeholders on what is needed.
But for me, it's still not enough.
So the intelligence team, from my perspective, not only have to be relevant and actionable
to the organization, but also have to be written or produced in the way that the implementation
of the findings and feedback loops will be quite frictionless.
So that each intelligence product that comes from the intelligence team to operation will
not burden the other side with difficulty of parsing and interpretation of data, but
will actually decrease time that they have to spend on the tiresome activities on the
alert fatigue and empower them to look for what the intelligence team pointed them to.
So the intelligence requirements problem, it's difficult to make good intelligence
requirements, period, I would say, and we can't expect that suddenly the teams which
might not have the experience with threat intelligence will come up with very, very
directed and very focused requirements that the intelligence team will know precisely
what they are looking for and so on.
More likely, this might initially come up as a very general requirements, like, you
know, tell me what are the threats to the organization and so on, which might be good
requirements, but probably will not be in the security operation environment.
Where the SOC analysts and responders and hunters are dealing with more tactical
oriented side of the things, so specific campaigns or specific malware and so on.
So it is necessary to work with those stakeholders to align and the benefit from
involvement of the intelligence team in the creation of requirements will be twofold.
First of all, the intelligence clients or the customers, or however you want to call
the recipients, will feel that they are actually part of this organization so that
intelligence team is working from them and the intelligence team will obviously know
what to deliver and how to make them visible in the organization.
In order to facilitate the creation of intelligence requirements, I've come up
with a method of considering three questions or three factors in terms of how the
intelligence products will then be processed in the further security organization.
So first of all, the question is about the location.
So who will use your intelligence or where the intelligence products will be delivered
after their creation, whether this will be a SOC team or the incident response team or
other stakeholders, and maybe even more importantly, where the intelligence team is
situated in regards to these teams in the organization.
So how close is the relationship between both teams?
Second question is how.
So how the intelligence products will be used.
Whether will you deliver a report that will have to be manually parsed and analyzed and
then the hunting team, for example, will create the relevant detection by themselves or
this will be a feed of IOCs in some or either in CSV or STIX format that can be
automatically parsed by the monitoring tools or what will be the technical workflow of
the intelligence of your inputs that will have to be processed.
And finally, and maybe most importantly, will those products be used at all?
So delivering the intelligence inputs or outputs of your process inputs for the
operations team, you have to consider all the time whether you will be providing them
with actual support or additional burden that will require them to introduce new
workflows or to spend a lot of time on parsing them and so on and so on.
So this last question will be, so to say, an amalgamation of previous two.
So whether your relationship with the other teams as an intelligence analyst will be
sufficient to correctly deliver the products and whether the format of them will be so
that they will be easily transposed into what is happening in the day-to-day work.
So starting with the who question, this is the question about, as I said, the location of
intelligence and the specifics of what will literally happen when you will click the send
button in Outlook or whether you will upload it to some threat intelligence platform, who will
see this notification, who will receive this email and how they will then download your
results into their specific team.
This is not only regarding the process of delivery itself, but also, or even more
importantly, about where your teams are aligned on the organizational chart.
As here, the location matters.
And why it matters, I grabbed here this very nice scheme or graphics from the Recorded
Future, where they present various security teams in the organization.
And what I like most about this graphics is that you can see that Threat Intel here just as a
one data point in the organization.
So we've got a bunch of those inputs and outputs and the levels of operation.
And you have to consider where the Threat Intelligence team is located.
So, for example, in my earlier work, I work in a setup where the Threat Intelligence team,
the Threat Hunting team and Incident Response was very closely in the organizational
structure. And I had to consider this in a way that, for example, when I delivered the
report to the Incident Response team, our interaction, as we were literally sitting in
the same room, will be much different than delivering the report to the SOC analysts who
are not directly in the same organizational structural place.
So when I delivered the report to the Incident Responder, I could literally walk to them and
talk about it and whether they like it or not, or what's their view on this and so on.
And this could not happen with some further teams.
And this directly correlates with how much feedback you will get, how much you can
fine-tune the report, how much should you care about whether the product will be
clear and easy to use.
Of course, it should be clear and easy to use in all your deliverables, but it is normal
that you will consider the fact that the closer you are in these charts, the more push and
the more influence you can have on how those are used, and the more feedback you can get
to even enable faster workflows and feedback loops of the fine-tuning of your intelligence
products. The second is how.
OK, so you deliver the report to the Incident Response team or to the SOC analyst, what
they will technically do with these things, whether they will have to parse it, they will
have to extract the indicators and put it in some other format, whether
the way that you are outputting intelligence, it maybe even
can work directly with the monitoring tools, because there is some plugin for
the SEM or for the EDR.
Basically, this is about the technical steps that the
analyst or the responder or other recipient have to perform to
make the intelligence part of their knowledge base, to make
it useful in the detection or in the contextualization of some activity.
This is the technical part.
And finally, while this is, of course, important and your reports should
definitely be aligned in a technical manner with what is
with the tech stack of the other organization, I believe that still the most important
question will be about the alignment with the overall day-to-day operation.
So as an artist here said, you are the only person who gets to decide what
you will remember for.
It is entirely up to you as a threat intelligence
analyst, whether you will be seen by the rest of the organization as a burden or
actual enabler of the more effective operations.
So getting straight into the specifics, you have to consider that on
daily basis, what will be the first thought that the operators or
analysts or responders have when they'll see your product.
Whether those will be another report that they have to manually parse and
include in the multiple tools that takes them like half an hour a day.
Whether this report will be delivered daily or more than daily so that even worse,
it can come into a situation that in multiple times you are interrupting the usual
workflow. So they will have to step away from the daily activities and
take care to introduce this intelligence into detection methods because this is the
latest and greatest threat to our organization.
And also, quite importantly, what will be the feedback mechanism?
So as we alluded to in the location question or hook question, what will be the
process of delivering do's and don'ts for your team back?
So whether this will be the situation, again, when you can just walk from one desk to
another to talk about it or this will have to be put in the mail because someone is
working maybe in a different country and in a different time zone and won't be able to
reach you directly.
And finally, after all these things are done, will you be able to measure an impact?
Because sometimes it might be hard to get this feedback and you might want to get some,
let's say, more direct or more objective data on how your intelligence is used.
So whether, in fact, your IOCs or behavioral analytics or something else is able to help
detect more incidents, whether time to remediation on the response side is deemed with
your intelligence products and so on and so on.
So the bottom line here is that the true effectiveness of the intelligence, threat
intelligence, intelligence products does not stem singularly from the alignments with the
technical stack and with the timeliness and relevance and actionability.
It stems from the frictionless introductions of the workloads of the other teams.
So that, in fact, I'm probably repeating myself, but this is the point that I want to drill
into. So it comes to whether these reports, when they land on the desk of other analysts,
whether they are seen as the helpful and useful product or input, or whether they are seen as
another checkbox to be ticked during the daily operations.
So, you know, there was a directive for SOC team to use the intelligence reports from our
intelligence team in their daily work.
And now every time they see an email pops up from the threat intelligence team at your
organization.com, they have to stay back and make some boring stuff to make it work.
And this is precisely as with the security awareness tips.
So often you can see this security awareness tips on, you should check every detail of your
mail, of the recipients, and you should get the header to see how the mail was delivered
between the gateways and so on and so on, and to check for typos and grammatical errors and so
on. And it drills down to the fact that you should, in fact, spend like half an hour on every
mail before you make a decision whether to even open it or to check anything.
And obviously, when you pass this kind of advice to your users, this will not happen because
that's not how the email works.
How the email works is that you've got a hundred messages in your inbox, maybe per hour or
something like that, and you have to skim through this.
And these tips, I really, really don't like them because they are just not relevant to how
email works. And this will be the same with your intelligence.
If your intelligence, it might be the best and the greatest and technically awesome, but if it
will require some bizarre, out of ordinary, out of workflow steps for the operators to use
them, this will simply be ignored and not used at all.
And based on this, using those frameworks that I've presented, let's now work on how to
make those intelligence requirements for different security teams.
So, as a general, especially in the beginning of the program, I believe one requirement
should answer one question.
So, for example, one question relevant to detection of certain family of malware or stuff
like that. Again, the requirements should be driven how day-to-day operations are working.
So, we will go deeper into that in a specific example, but they should stem from how the
analysts or responders or whatever are working with their products.
Talking about security operation and intelligence teams, I think it's a bit easier than
talking about the intelligence team and executive board or this level of stakeholders,
because they will be closer on the organizational chart, as we talked about, and they
will be probably much more granular in terms of what is expected from you.
So, you will be able to focus more on very specific cases, which I think will be
easier for the analysts.
So, now feast your eyes with this graph that I prepared entirely in PowerPoint.
So, this is how, in my view, the feedback loop should operate between the intelligence,
hunting or SOC, so monitoring team, and the incident response.
So, from my point of view, it is necessary that those feedback loops goes in both ways in
case of all three elements of this structure.
So, we can start with this very simple loop that should be kind of natural, so that
intelligence works on analysis of some threats.
It provides the description of activity to build some behavioral analytics or just IOCs
for the SOC analysts and the hunting team to introduce into the detection workflow.
And then when the hunting team finds something or the SOC analyst gets an alert and flags
it as a true positive, it gathers some data and passes it to the incident response to
remediate it, contain it, and so on, follow the incident response cycle.
And obviously, the incident response will find more and more details about this
activity, and then it will finally, closing the loop, provides it to the intelligence.
So, they will dissect and analyze it, perhaps look for some malware samples on
VirusTotal, and based on that, they will build a profile and pass it to the hunting
and monitoring, and so on, and the loop closes.
But also importantly for me, the reverse loops, mainly concerned with the feedback,
are essential.
So, as we talked about this in the Spider-Man meme, the intelligence also wants this data
from the incident response teams, but it has to also be able to deliver.
So, in terms of incident response team, one way it goes that after the incident response
data is passed to the intelligence team using this F3EAD exploit to analyze and dissect
activity, but on the other hand, when the incident response team is dealing with
something, they will have an intelligence requirement to produce context on some
activity. So, they can remediate it faster, discover the whole scope of this activity
sooner, and so on.
And when they will have this whole picture, they can provide feedback on fidelity and
quality of detection to the monitoring team who found the activity in the first place.
And similarly, the intelligence provided some description of the behavior to the
monitoring team, so they can find the evil in the organization.
But the hunting and the SOC can provide the intelligence with frontline data, what they
see on a daily basis, some trends, the most commonly used version of implants and malware
and so on. So, they can again proceed with the exploit, analyze and dissect and produce
more and more better intelligence.
So, going now to the specific examples of how this can work.
So, starting from the SOC analyst, SOC analyst will most likely want the situational
awareness, tactical information on what is going on in the wild, what they can expect
from the monitoring tools to alert them on and how they can find more information about
these activities, prepare better for the incident response and so on.
So, delivering the intelligence to security operations center will much depend on the
maturity of SOC. In my experience, I mean, it depends on what is the actual role of SOC,
let's say, first tier, first line analyst, whether he just looks at the alerts that he has a
little control of the architecture of security controls and can just input or look for IP
addresses to block, or whether he actually can proceed with deeper investigations and, for
example, passing this composite object of the indicator, like the data on the registration of
domain, they will be able to work with that to introduce it into the monitoring effort.
So, example here, most straightforward and most common will be probably closing up of the
security tools. So, intelligence team finds something that is not detected by the current
monitoring setup and they will pulse it for SOC to add the specific indicators that can put a
bandaid on the current situation.
So, coming back to our framework of who, how and will, who is the security operations center?
The operators, analysts who daily work with the monitoring solutions, how they will implement the
signature that you will provide them in their monitoring tool, be it SCM or EDR or anything they
work from. And will, so does the solution that they use will frictionless support the input you
provide? So, for example, you deliver a CSV with indicator as a part of the, of your intelligence
workflow. Is it as simple as uploading the CSV file to the tool and it will be parsed automatically?
And this is done on the part of the SOC analyst, or maybe even better, you just upload this CSV to
Threat Intelligence Platform and it will be populated automatically. And then SOC analysts only have to
recognize that this comes from Threat Intelligence and should be treated with certain attention.
Or the situation is completely other way around that SOC analysts have to manually parse the inputs
and put the indicators manually. And in that case, you may want to focus on maybe the most important
ones or only the criticals, the criticals that will have to be alerted and so on. So the requirement
that can be created based on this framework, maybe provide a method of detection of implant, because
this from the intelligence finding, this is our detection gap, the implant inks in format that will
support our tool. So that again, coming back to this point about frictionless introduction, for the
analyst, the introduction, if intelligence will not take them back from their main job,
which is detecting and alerting on evil in the organization, and they will be able to
quickly deliver those results. Then another example, intelligence and incident response.
Incident responders most likely will want to have a context of the activity
they analyze. So they are in the middle of investigation, they found this specific
payload or installed implant, or they found that this certain activity like exfiltration or
attempt to destroy the evidence is going on in the organization. And they will want to know
where to pivot their investigation from there to discover the whole scope of the activity.
And so again, coming to our framework of WHW, who the incident responders will get the intel,
and what they will do, they will look under your intelligence reports, they will look at
their forensic report in the making, and they will probably cross-reference it to see if in
fact this activity that you are describing is what is going on in the environment. And if it is,
they will pivot to looking for the specifics, looking for other signs of the activity
based on what you provide with them. And will they use it? Well, they might if the description
that you have of the activity that you have in your report or other deliverable will match with
what the incident response team is going through in their standard workflow. So for example,
you have to understand whether the incident response is using a certain live response tool
to collect evidence, or maybe they have a custom solution that they use, and in the first place,
they are going for memory forensics or for file system forensics. And working on that, you will
be able to construct your intelligence product in a way that will catch their attention,
because for example, they are going through memory forensics, first point. And in this case,
you will provide them with some description of how the malicious processes are created,
they process trees, they have what handles they open, and so on. So when the responder sees it,
they will see, aha, this is precisely what I'm working for, and I can see whether there are some
matches. And requirements based on this, so describe this activity of other adversary in
terms of the specific artifacts, like the output of memory forensics, output of this forensics,
network artifacts, and so on, and so on. And the third example, the intelligence and hunting.
So I spent, I would say, most impactful parts of my career in the hunting role, so I will have
some obvious biases. I think there can be hardly an intelligence, sorry, hardly the
the hunting efforts, proper hunting efforts without intelligence, because otherwise it is
guessing. You might have the best ideas about this, some potentially dangerous activity that
might happen in your environment, and on paper, it's perfect. But if you will not have this
intelligence understanding, or whether this is actually used by some threat actors, or this is
relevant to your threat profile, then the returns from the hunting will be severely diminished.
And the second bias that I have is that the only limiting, sorry for the typo factor,
is how much the hunting team can take. So from my perspective, the hunting efforts are the,
like, let's say third line activities, and this is where the detection should shine in order to
detect those highly evasive threats. So the more advanced intelligence, the more
in-depth technical, basically, the better. So what this does to our WHW framework,
the threat hunters will receive those intelligence, and using those, they will build a hypothesis
on how this activity can be detected in the environment. So will they use it? They will,
if they will have, if the visibility they have matches with what your intelligence products
describe. So obviously, when you will describe some great and sweet network indicator, but on
daily work, they are not working with that at all. They are using, they have little visibility,
and that's not what they focus. It's highly unlikely that it will be perfectly utilized.
So again, you have to, just with incident responders and daily workflows, you should
work with hunters to establish what are their favorite things to hunt in, what are their
favorite types of logs, and then attempt to, for example, describe the malware installation
mechanism in terms of command line syntax. So summing up this part of the presentation,
there is one thing I would like to also emphasize, because there's often comes a
dilemma of consumption and generation of intelligence. So should you move to this
generation or is it enough for you to just consume the reports of other vendors and so on?
And this is, again, where the requirements were based on those earlier suggestions might shine,
because when you have intelligence requirements that were tailored to the workflows of specific
teams, you can accurately assess whether there is a need to generate intelligence, because those
gaps cannot be fulfilled with the consumption of some third-party free or paid reports.
Or whether there is, for example, the response team needs this context of the incident,
and all the other vendors just cannot satisfy this with how they are reporting. And then you can
assess whether the additional efforts by the intelligence team will be worth this additional
visibility in the organization. So this is the way, again, that recruiters can support in
very common problems. Okay, so I guess this is my thing, what I wanted to tell you today.
Hope you enjoyed it, and if you have any questions, I'm here to answer them. Thank you a lot.
